_accidents.CI_OtherType: Retraining of employee that was injured

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:



Whelan Energy Center is a two unit, coal-fired electric generating facility, which is located two miles east of the City of Hastings in Adams County, Nebraska.  Whelan Energy Center Unit 2 is owned by the Public Power Generation Agency (PPGA), which consists of a number of partners, including Hastings Utilities, which operates the facility. Whelan Energy Center Unit 2 uses anhydrous ammonia in the operation of its selective catalytic reduction (SCR) pollution prevention system. Anhydrous ammonia is the only Risk Management Program (RMP) listed chemical that is present at Whelan Energy Center above the threshold quantity.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:



Hastings Utilities is committed to employee and public safety and the protection of the environment. 



The basis of Hastings Utilities' Accidental Release Prevention Program is sound engineering, effective operating procedures, and robust training and maintenance programs. Hastings Utilities employees are not trained to respond to releases, but Hastings Utilities works closely with the local emergency agencies to ensure that they are prepared to respond to releases.



Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:



Hastings Utilities' Program 2 Prevention Program for the anhydrous ammonia system is a rigorous program which incorporates all of the required elements:



    - Safety information is compiled, maintained on-site, and updated as necessary. 



    - A hazard review has been conducted using a "What if" methodology with significant input from employees.  The findings of the hazard review and actions taken as a result of the findings are documented. 



    - Written operating procedures have been developed for the safe storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia at Whelan Energy Center Unit 2. The procedures specify steps for each operating phase.  Procedures are updated, as necessary.

- A training program has been established related to the operation, inspection, and maintenance of the anhydrous ammonia system to ensure safe operation.



    - Hastings Utilities' has written procedures for maintaining the process equipment and has identified necessary checks and inspections. Operators perform visual inspections on the ammonia process equipment as part of their plant tour, which is required at least once per day.



    - A thorough and detailed compliance audit was conducted in 2013, and a report developed of the audit findings. This was the first compliance audit required for the facility.



    - There have been no incidents involving ammonia at Whelan Energy Center that resulted in, or could have resulted in, a catastrophic release. However, a core incident investigation team has been identified and procedures are in place to conduct an incident investigation, should an incident occur.



All of the elements of Hastings Utilities' Program 2 Prevention Program have been developed with the intent of preventing the accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.



Five-Year Accident History:



On June 27, 2011, an accidental release of ammonia occurred at the facility. The ammonia vaporizer system had been taken out of service for maintenance.  The vent valves are supposed to be closed (locked-out/tagged-out) when the system is taken out of service, but one of the vent valves was left open. The vent valves are also supposed to be checked to make sure they are closed prior to returning the system to operation, but the operator who returned the system to service neglected to check if any of the vent valves were left open. When the vaporizer system was returned to service, a small amount of ammonia was released from the open vent valve. The operator was in the vicinity of the valve and sustained minor injuries from the ammonia. The operator went to the hospital, and the injuries were confirmed to have been minor.   



As a result of the accide

nt, the operator was retrained on the safe operation of the ammonia system. Also as a result of the accident, Hastings Utilities is in the process of revising the lock-out/tag-out policy to require two individuals to verify that equipment has been properly locked-out/tagged out prior to maintenance of the equipment, to help prevent this type of accident from occurring in the future. All plant employees will be trained on the new lock-out/tag-out policy.



Emergency Response Program:



Hastings Utilities' employees are not trained as first responders.  In the event of a significant release, site personnel will follow the emergency action plan which includes notification of the control room. The control room will contact emergency services by dialing 911, so that the appropriate fire and rescue, police, ambulance and emergency management services can be dispatched, as warranted by the situation.



Hastings Utilities works closely with local emergency personnel to ensure that responders are familiar with the anhydrous ammonia process, its location, and the potential risks.



All site personnel have received initial ammonia training on ammonia hazards, how they can be identified, and what to do in the event of a release.  In addition, operators and maintenance personnel who work with the ammonia system have been instructed on the proper use and maintenance of the equipment. Several of the Hastings Utilities' employees have taken HAZWOPER training, which provides additional training on the proper use of ammonia.



Hastings Utilities considers the delivery of ammonia at the site to be one of the highest risk activities.  Unloading is done by the ammonia vendor's qualified personnel.  As an additional safety measure, Hastings Utilities stations a trained person to observe the ammonia unloading and intervene, if necessary.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



Hastings Utilities is continually evaluating the hazards of operation of the anhydrous ammonia system.  As

a result of the minor accident that occurred involving ammonia, Hastings Utilities is in the process of revising the lock-out/tag-out policy to require two individuals to verify that equipment has been properly locked-out/tagged out prior to maintenance of the equipment and returning the system to service. All plant employees will be trained on the new lock-out/tag-out policy.
